title: Black Money: India Gets Names, Addresses & Balance Details Of Swiss Bank Account Holders
text:
Black money was a reeling cry a few years ago in India as Manmohan Singh-led UPA II government collapsed against the backdrop of serious allegations of corruption against it. About six years down the line and India has now received the first tranche of details about financial accounts of its residents in Swiss banks under a new automatic exchange of information framework between the two countries.

Swiss banks have long been described as a safe heaven for Indians to hide their black money and every time that an election approaches, it is used as a tool by the political class.

This, however, marks a significant milestone in the fight against black money suspected to be stashed abroad, news agency PTI reported on Monday.

India figures among 75 countries with which Switzerland's Federal Tax Administration (FTA) has exchanged information on financial accounts within the framework of global standards on AEOI, an FTA spokesperson was quoted as saying by PTI.

This is the first time that India has received details from Switzerland under the AEOI framework, which provides for exchange of information on financial accounts that are currently active as well as those accounts that were closed during 2018.

REPRESENTATIVE IMAGE. BCCL

The next exchange would take place in September 2020. However, the exchange is governed by strict confidentiality clauses and the FTA officials refused to disclose specific details on the number of accounts or about the quantum of financial assets associated with the accounts of Indian clients of Swiss banks.

The exchanged information include identification, account and financial information. These include name, address, state of residence and tax identification number, as well as information concerning the financial institution, account balance and capital income.

Asked about specific details relating to India, the FTA spokesperson said, "The communication of statistical data is subject to the confidentiality clauses as well."

The Swiss government said Switzerland has committed itself to adopting the global standard for the international automatic exchange of information in tax matters.

It is feared many Indians might have closed their accounts after a global crackdown on black money led to Switzerland buckling under pressure to open its banking sector for scrutiny to clear the long-held perception of Swiss banks being safe haven for undisclosed funds.
